required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Impacts of Static Magnetic Fields on Dysmenorrhea Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Impacts of Static Magnetic Fields on Dysmenorrhea Pain

brief_summary.textblock: Study to determine the effectiveness of a certain type of magnet to reduce period pain

detailed_description.textblock: Young women with their period pain levels of 6 or greater on a pain scale of 0-10 will wear a concentric magnet or a sham that is positioned close to the maximum pain site. The pain score after wearing either the magnet or sham will be recorded.

study_design_info.masking_description: Magnet and sham devices used weigh and look the same

primary_outcome.measure: Pain score scale of 1-10 / 1 being less pain 10 being more pain
primary_outcome.description: Subject reported pain after wearing device

arm_group.description: Women wearing magnet a magnet, or sham device indistinguishable from the magnet (determined randomly), will be placed on her abdomen. If the pain is predominately in her abdomen, the device will be placed on the location with the most pain. If the pain is predominantly in the subjects back, the device will be placed on the lower abdomen on the midline between the umbilicus and the pubic bone.

Women wearing sham a magnet, or sham device indistinguishable from the magnet (determined randomly), will be placed on her abdomen. If the pain is predominately in her abdomen, the device will be placed on the location with the most pain. If the pain is predominantly in the subjects back, the device will be placed on the lower abdomen on the midline between the umbilicus and the pubic bone.

intervention.description: Magnet or Sham is worn by subject in close proximity to their described maximum pain site

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: Female with period pain score consistently equal to or greater than 6 on a pain scale of 0-10 -
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Pain not experienced on almost all menstrual cycles
2. Having secondary dysmenorrhea including endometriosis, fibroids or pelvic inflammatory disease
3. Having a pacemaker or any implanted wires or devices -

eligibility.gender_description: Ages 18-35 years of age with period pain score consistently equal to or greater than 6 on a pain scale of 0-10
